sipunculus: <entryFree id="n44433" type="main" key="si_punculus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">sīpunculus</orth>, v. siphunculus.</entryFree>
sipus: <entryFree id="n44434" type="main" key="Si_pu_s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Sīpūs</orth>, <itype>untis</itype>, v. Sipontum.</entryFree>
sipyleius: <entryFree id="n44435" type="main" key="Si^py^le_ius"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Sĭpylēïus</orth> <itype>a, um</itype>, and <orth extent="full" lang="la">Sĭpylēus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, and <orth extent="full" lang="la">Sĭpylensis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, v. Sipylus.</entryFree>
sipylus: <entryFree id="n44436" type="main" key="Si^py^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Sĭpylus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*si/pulos</foreign>. <sense id="n44436.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A mountain on the frontiers of Lydia and Phrygia</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on which Niobe was changed into stone</hi>, the modern <hi rend="ital">Manisa Dagh</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:2:20" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 2, 20</bibl> (3, 13), 8; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:6:149" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 6, 149</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:2:11:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Q. Fr. 2, 11, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Herc. Oet. 184" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Herc. Oet. 184</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Agam. 374" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Agam. 374</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Sĭpylē-us</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">of Sipylus</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">genitrix Sipylea,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>Niobe</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:5:1:33" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 5, 1, 33</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">also called Sipyleïa cautes,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Epit. 27</bibl></cit>.—<orth extent="full" lang="la">Sĭpylen-sis</orth>, e: <cit><quote lang="la">mater deorum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Ulp.</author> Fragm. 22, 6</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n44436.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A son of Niobe</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:6:231" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 6, 231</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
siquando: <entryFree id="n44437" type="main" key="si_quando_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">sīquandō</orth> (better separate, <orth extent="full" lang="la">sī quan-dō</orth>), <pos>adv.</pos>, <sense id="n44437.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">if ever</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:15:52" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Lael. 15, 52</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:64:section=142" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 64, § 142</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:38:59" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 1, 38, 59</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:98" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 98</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 12</bibl>. 851 al.—<usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:2:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> A. A. 2, 15</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Achill. 1, 509 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
siquidem: <entryFree id="n44438" type="main" key="si_qui^dem"><orth extent="full" lang="la">sīquĭdem</orth> (or separate, <orth extent="full" lang="la">sī quĭdem</orth>; in poets, <orth extent="full" lang="la">sĭquĭdem</orth>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:10:104" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 10, 104</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">11</bibl>, <cb n="SIRE" /> 219; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:3:7:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Am. 3, 7, 17</bibl>), <pos>adv.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">ei)/per</foreign>. <sense id="n44438.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">If only</hi>, <hi rend="ital">if indeed</hi> (class.): <cit><quote lang="la">actumst, siquidem haec vera praedicat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:3:1:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 3, 1, 7</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">gratulor Baiis nostris, si quidem, ut scribis, salubres repente factae sunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:12:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 9, 12, 1</bibl></cit>: robur et suboles militum interiit, si quidem quae nuntiantur ullā ea parte vera sunt, Asin. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:10:33:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 10, 33, 1</bibl>: <hi rend="ital">Sy.</hi> Quid aliud tibi vis? <hi rend="ital">Cl.</hi> Siquidem hoc fit. <hi rend="ital">Sy.</hi> Siquidem? experiundo scies, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:2:3:90" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 2, 3, 90</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">o fortunatam rem publicam, si quidem hanc sentinam urbis ejecerit!</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:2:4:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 2, 4, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">O morem praeclarum, si quidem teneremus!</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fl. 7</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n44438.1" n="II" level="1"> Like quandoquidem, <hi rend="ital">since indeed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">since</hi>, <hi rend="ital">since that</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">si quidem mihi saltandumst, jam vos date bibat tibicini,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:5:5:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Stich. 5, 5, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">siquidem ille ipse non volt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:4:1:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 4, 1, 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">siquidem Homerus fuit ante Romam conditam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:1:3" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 1, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:10:39" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 10, 39</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:24:81" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 24, 81</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:1:9" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 1, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:6:15 al" default="NO">1, 6, 15 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">(pinus) grata deum matri, siquidem Attis Exuit hac hominem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:10:104" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 10, 104</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
siquis: <entryFree id="n44439" type="main" key="si_quis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">sī-quis</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">sī-qui</orth>, <itype>sīqua, sīquid or sīquod, or separately</itype>, <orth extent="full" lang="la">sī quis</orth>, etc., <sense id="n44439.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">indef. pron.</hi> (v. Zumpt, Gr. § 740), <hi rend="ital">if any</hi>, <hi rend="ital">if any one</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">si quis recte Tractaret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:1:1:100" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 1, 1, 100</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si qui (filius) natus esset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:12:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 12, 33</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si qua tui Corydonis habet te cura,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:7:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 7, 40</bibl></cit>.—Adverb.: si qui and si qua, <hi rend="ital">if in any way</hi>, <hi rend="ital">if by any means</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">si qui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 64 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:1:2:83" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 1, 2, 83</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">si qua,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,007:1:3:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cist. 1, 3, 35</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 18</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:14:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 14, 19</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">si quo,</quote> <trans><tr>if any whither</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:8:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 8, 2, 1</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">also,</quote> <trans><tr>if for any purpose</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:37:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 37, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si quid,</quote> <trans><tr>if at all</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:688" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 688</bibl></cit>; cf. 2. quis.</sense></entryFree>
siraci: <entryFree id="n44440" type="main" key="Siraci"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Siraci</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n44440.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a people of Asiatic Sarmatia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:83" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 12, 26, § 83</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Tac.</author> 12, 15</bibl> and 16.</sense></entryFree>
sirae: <entryFree id="n44441" type="main" key="Sirae"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Sirae</orth>, <itype>ārum</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n44441.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town of the Odomantic region in Thrace</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:45:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 45, 4</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
siraeum: <entryFree id="n44442" type="greek" key="si^raeum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">sĭraeum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">si/raion</foreign>, <sense id="n44442.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">new wine boiled down</hi> (pure Lat. sapa), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:14:80" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 14, 9, 11, § 80</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
sirbenus: <entryFree id="n44443" type="greek" key="sirbe_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">sirbēnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">surbhno/s</foreign>, <sense id="n44443.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">speaking confusedly</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">virgo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1248,001:, Or. 3" default="NO"><author>Fronto</author>, Or. 3</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
sirbitum: <entryFree id="n44444" type="main" key="Sirbitum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Sirbitum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <sense id="n44444.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a city in Ethiopia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:194 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 6, 30, 35, § 194 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
sirbonis: <entryFree id="n44445" type="main" key="Sirbonis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Sirbonis</orth> <itype>lacus</itype>, <sense id="n44445.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a lake on the borders of Palestine</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:68" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 13, 14, § 68</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
sircitula: <entryFree id="n44446" type="hapax" key="sircitu^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">sircitŭla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n44446.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a kind of grape</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:12:45:1" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 12, 45, 1</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
sircula: <entryFree id="n44447" type="main" key="sircu^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">sircŭla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n44447.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a kind of grape</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:14:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 14, 2, 4, § 34</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
siredones: <entryFree id="n44448" type="main" key="Si_re_do^nes"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Sīrēdŏnes</orth>, <itype>um</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = Sirenes, <sense id="n44448.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the Sirens</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Idyll. 11, 20</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
siremps: <entryFree id="n44449" type="main" key="si^remps"><orth extent="full" lang="la">sĭremps</orth> (<orth extent="full" lang="la">sĭrempse</orth>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:prol. 73" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. prol. 73</bibl>), <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>acc. to Fest. pp. 344 and 345 Müll., contr. from similis re ipsā, qs. simrepsa, simrepse, and by transposition, sirempse; but prob. from si-, loc. form from pronom. stem sa-, cf. sic; rem is acc. of reference, cf. prope-diem, pri-dem; -pe is the intens. part., as in nem-pe, etc., and becomes pse, with enclit. se, as in ipse, etc., v. Corss. Ausspr. 2, 846 sq.</etym>; publicists' t. t., of a like application of laws, <sense id="n44449.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">like</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the same</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">sirempse legem jussit esse Juppiter,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:prol. 73" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. prol. 73</bibl></cit>: siremps lex, S. C. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1245,001:Aquaed. 129" default="NO"><author>Front.</author> Aquaed. 129</bibl>; so Tab. Bantina, C. I. L. 197, 13; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1245,001:198:73" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 198, 73</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1245,001:200:27" default="NO">200, 27</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1245,001:202:1" default="NO">202, 1</bibl>; 202, 38; 205, 2 al.; Lex ap. Grut. 508, 21; 628 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>; 629, 1; Cato ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:1" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> 1</bibl>. 1.: <cit><quote lang="la">omnium quae terram premunt, siremps, lex esto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 91:16" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 91, 16</bibl></cit>; cf. Marin. Fratr. Arval. p. 568.</sense></entryFree>
siren: <entryFree id="n44450" type="main" key="Si_re_n"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Sīrēn</orth>, <itype>ēnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*seirh/n</foreign>, <sense id="n44450.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Siren.</hi> </sense><sense id="n44450.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, usu. <number>plur.</number>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Sīrēnes</orth>, <itype>um</itype>, = <foreign lang="greek">*seirh=nes</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">the Sirens</hi>, who, according to the myth, were birds with the faces of virgins. They dwelt on the southern coast of Italy, where, with their sweet voices, they enticed ashore those who were sailing by, and then killed them, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:5:555" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 5, 555</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 125" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 125</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:141" default="NO">141</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> Verg. A. 5, 864</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:5:18:49" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 5, 18, 49</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:3:12" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 3, 12</bibl> (4, 11), 34; <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 2, 23</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:3:64:1" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 3, 64, 1</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> R. Am. 789</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:136 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 49, 70, § 136 al.</bibl>—<hi rend="ital">Sing.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Siren,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:14:473" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 14, 473</bibl></cit>; cf. infra, 2.: scopuli Sirenum, <hi rend="ital">three small islands of rock on the south-west coast of Campania</hi>, <hi rend="ital">between Surrentum and Capreœ;</hi> in Gr. <foreign lang="greek">*seirhnou=sai</foreign>, now <hi rend="ital">Galli</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:864" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 864</bibl> Heyne; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:88" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 88</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">also called Sirenum petrae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:2:4:9" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 2, 4, 9</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <hi rend="ital">strange birds</hi>: Sirenes in delubris voluptatum, <hi rend="ital">owls</hi> or <hi rend="ital">ostriches</hi>, Vulg. lsa. 13, 22.—</sense><sense id="n44450.2" n="2" level="3"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n44450.3" n="(a)" level="5"> Of <hi rend="ital">the drones</hi> in a hive: <cit><quote lang="la">fuci (vocantur) sirenes aut cephenes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 16, 16, § 48</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n44450.4" n="(b)" level="5"> <usg type="style">Poet.</usg>: Cato Grammaticus, Latina Siren, <hi rend="ital">the Latin Siren</hi> (as master of song), <cb n="SISE" /> Poët. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,004:11" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Gram. 11</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui gaudet acerbo Plagarum strepitu et nullam Sirena flagellis Comparat,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>thinks no Siren's song equal to the sound of the whip</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:14:19" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 14, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vitanda est improba Siren Desidia,</quote> <trans><tr>allurer</tr>, <tr>seducer</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:3:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 3, 14</bibl></cit>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n44450.5" n="A" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Sīrē-nĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to the Sirens</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Siren-</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">scopuli, i. q. Sirenum scopuli (v. supra, I.),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:16:8:17" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 16, 8, 17</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 29, 2, 14</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n44450.6" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Sīrēnaeus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">Siren-</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cantus,</quote> <trans><tr>Siren-song</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hier.</author> Ep. 82, 5</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n44450.7" n="C" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Sī-rēnis</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <hi rend="ital">adj. f.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">of the Sirens</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> Perieg. 354</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n44450.8" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A kind of drones</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 16, 16, § 48</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
sirena: <entryFree id="n44451" type="main" key="Si_re_na"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Sīrēna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, later collat. form of Siren, q. v.; <case>abl.</case> Sirenā, Phil. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:564" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 564</bibl>; <number>plur.</number>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Hier.</author> Ep. 22</bibl> (18), 6; 18; Schol. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:9:150" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 9, 150</bibl>: <sense id="n44451.0" n="I" level="1"><cit><quote lang="la">mortifera Sirenarum carmina,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hier.</author> Ep. 54</bibl></cit> (47), 13: <cit><quote lang="la">cantus Sirenarum, Ambros. de Jac. et Vit. Beat. 2, 12, 56: scopuli Sirenarum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Mart. Cap.</author> 6, § 641</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Cyclopum et Sirenarum ora,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Apol. 7</bibl></cit> (Oehl. Sirenum).</sense></entryFree>
sirenaeus: <entryFree id="n44452" type="main" key="Si_re_naeus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Sīrēnaeus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, v. Sirenes, I. B.</entryFree>
siria: <entryFree id="n44453" type="main" key="Siria"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Siria</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, v. Syria.</entryFree>
siriacus: <entryFree id="n44454" type="greek" key="si_ri^a^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">sīrĭăcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">seiriako/s</foreign>, <sense id="n44454.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to the dog-star</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">calor,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Avien.</author> Arat. 285</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
siriasis: <entryFree id="n44455" type="greek" key="si_ri^a^sis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">sīrĭăsis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">seiri/asis</foreign>, <sense id="n44455.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an inflammatory disease of children</hi>, <hi rend="ital">siriasis</hi>, occasioned by excessive heat of the sun, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:30:135" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 30, 15, 47, § 135</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:32:138" default="NO" valid="yes">32, 10, 48, § 138</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:22:59" default="NO" valid="yes">22, 21, 29, § 59</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
siris: <entryFree id="n44456" type="main" key="siris1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">siris</orth>, <orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">sirit</orth>, etc., v. sino <sense id="n44456.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">init.</hi></sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n44457" type="main" key="Si_ris2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Sīris</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*si/ris</foreign>. <sense id="n44457.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The name of a branch of the Nile in Ethiopia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 9, 10, § 54</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> Perieg. 212</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n44457.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A river in Italy</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:97" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 11, 15, § 97</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n44457.2" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A name for Heraclea in</hi> Magna Graecia, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:97" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 11, 15, § 97</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
sirium: <entryFree id="n44458" type="main" key="si_ri^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">sīrĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <sense id="n44458.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a plant</hi>, <hi rend="ital">called also</hi> artemisia <hi rend="ital">and</hi> serpyllum majus, <hi rend="ital">mugwort</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Herb. 10</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
sirius: <entryFree id="n44459" type="greek" key="Si_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Sīrĭus</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">sei/rios</foreign>, <sense id="n44459.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the dog-star</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Sirius</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Astr. 3:34" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Astr. 3, 34</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:2:35" default="NO">2, 35</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:425" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 425</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:141" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 3, 141</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:1:7:21" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 1, 7, 21</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:10:211 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 10, 211 al.</bibl>—<hi rend="ital">Adj.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ardor,</quote> <trans><tr>of Sirius</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:10:273" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 10, 273</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">Col. poët. 10, 289: vapor,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Prud.</author> Cath. 12, 22</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
sirmio: <entryFree id="n44460" type="main" key="Sirmio"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Sirmio</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n44460.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a peninsula on the shores of the</hi> Lacus Benacus, <hi rend="ital">in Upper Italy</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Sermione</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:32:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 32, 1</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
sirmium: <entryFree id="n44461" type="main" key="Sirmium"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Sirmium</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <sense id="n44461.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an important city of</hi> Pannonia Inferior, now <hi rend="ital">Mitrovitz</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Pan. 774</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Ep. 26, 1</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
siromastes: <entryFree id="n44462" type="greek" key="si_romastes"><orth extent="full" lang="la">sīromastes</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">seiroma/sths</foreign>, <sense id="n44462.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a pit-searcher</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an instrument used by taxgatherers in probing corn-pits</hi>, etc. (late Lat.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Hier.</author> Ep. 109, 3</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">147, 9</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
sirona: <entryFree id="n44463" type="gloss" key="Si^ro_na"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Sĭrōna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n44463.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">name of a goddess among the Gauls</hi>, coupled with APOLLO, <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 2001</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2047</bibl> sq.</sense></entryFree>
sirpe: <entryFree id="n44464" type="greek" key="sirpe"><orth extent="full" lang="la">sirpe</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym><foreign lang="greek">si/lfion</foreign></etym>, <sense id="n44464.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a plant</hi>, <hi rend="ital">called also</hi> silphium <hi rend="ital">and</hi> laser, <hi rend="ital">asafœtida</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:3:2:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 3, 2, 16</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Sol.</author> 27, § 48</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
sirpea: <entryFree id="n44465" type="main" key="sirpe^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">sirpĕa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, v. scirpeus.</entryFree>
sirpiculus: <entryFree id="n44466" type="main" key="sirpi^cu^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">sirpĭcŭlus</orth>, v. scirpiculus.</entryFree>
sirpicus: <entryFree id="n44467" type="hapax" key="sirpi^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">sirpĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>sirpe</etym>, <sense id="n44467.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to the plant</hi> sirpe: <cit><quote lang="la">lac,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Sol.</author> 27, § 49</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
sirpo: <entryFree id="n44468" type="main" key="sirpo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">sirpo</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, v. scirpo.</entryFree>
sirpus: <entryFree id="n44469" type="main" key="sirpus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">sirpus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, v. scirpus.</entryFree>
sirus: <entryFree id="n44470" type="greek" key="si_rus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">sīrus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">siro/s</foreign>, <sense id="n44470.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a pit</hi> to keep corn in, <hi rend="ital">an underground granary</hi> (cf. cumera), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:18:306" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 18, 30, 73, § 306</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:1:6:15" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 1, 6, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:7:4:24" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 7, 4, 24</bibl>; cf. Auct. B. Afr. 65; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:6:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 6, 8</bibl> (<bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:57" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 57</bibl> and 63, written as Greek).</sense></entryFree>
sis: <entryFree id="n44471" type="main" key="si_s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">sīs</orth>. <sense id="n44471.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Subj.</hi> of sum.—</sense><sense id="n44471.1" n="II" level="1"> Contr. from si vis; v. volo <hi rend="ital">init.</hi>—</sense><sense id="n44471.2" n="III" level="1"> I. q. suis, v. suus <hi rend="ital">init.</hi></sense></entryFree>
sisapo: <entryFree id="n44472" type="main" key="Sisa^po"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Sisăpo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n44472.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a small town in</hi> Hispania Baetica, <hi rend="ital">rich in mines of cinnabar</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Almaden in the Sierra Morena</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 1, 3, § 14</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:19:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 2, 19, 48</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Sisăpōnensis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to Sisapo</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Sisaponian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">regio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:33:121" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 33, 7, 40, § 121</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">minarii,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:33:121" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 33, 7, 40, § 121</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
sisara: <entryFree id="n44473" type="main" key="sisa^ra"><orth extent="full" lang="la">sisăra</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n44473.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a name among the Eubœans for the plant</hi> erice, <hi rend="ital">heath</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sweetbroom</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 16, 15, § 42</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:16" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 16</bibl>. 26.</sense></entryFree>
siscia: <entryFree id="n44474" type="main" key="Siscia"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Siscia</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n44474.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a city of Pannonia</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Siszek</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:113" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 113</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:147" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 25, 28, § 147</bibl>; Prud. <foreign lang="greek">stef</foreign>. 7, 3.</sense></entryFree>
sisenna: <entryFree id="n44475" type="main" key="Si_senna"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Sīsenna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n44475.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Roman surname.</hi> </sense><sense id="n44475.1" n="I" level="1"> L. Cornehus, <hi rend="ital">a celebrated Roman historian</hi>, <hi rend="ital">born about</hi> A.U.C. 635, <hi rend="ital">author of a Roman history</hi> (Historiae). He preceded <pb n="1711" /> <cb n="SIST" /> Sallust, who took him as a model, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:64:228" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 64, 228</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:1:2:7" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Leg. 1, 2, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 95:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 95, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:2:443" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 2, 443</bibl>; v. the fragments, Krause, Vit. et Fragm. Hist. Rom. p. 303 sq.—</sense><sense id="n44475.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The name of a notorious slanderer in Rome</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:7:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 7, 8</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
siser: <entryFree id="n44476" type="greek" key="si^ser"><orth extent="full" lang="la">sĭser</orth>, <itype>ĕris</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> (<sense id="n44476.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">masc.</hi> in <number>plur.</number> siseres, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:20:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 20, 5, 17, § 35</bibl>) [<foreign lang="greek">si/saron</foreign>], <hi rend="ital">a plant with an esculent root</hi>, <hi rend="ital">skirwort</hi> or <hi rend="ital">skirret</hi>: Sium sisarum, Linn.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:19:90" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 19, 5, 28, § 90</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:20:35" default="NO" valid="yes">20, 5, 17, § 35</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:11:3:18" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 11, 3, 18</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:11:3:35" default="NO">11, 3, 35</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:12:58:3" default="NO">12, 58, 3</bibl>; 10, 114.</sense></entryFree>
sisichthon: <entryFree id="n44477" type="greek" key="Si_sichthon"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Sīsichthon</orth>, <itype>ŏnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*seisi/xqwn</foreign>, <sense id="n44477.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">Earth-shaker</hi>, an epithet of Neptune, <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 17, 7, 12</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
sisonagrion: <entryFree id="n44478" type="main" key="sison agrion"><orth extent="full" lang="la">sison agrion</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <sense id="n44478.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a plant</hi>, <hi rend="ital">also called</hi> peucedanos <hi rend="ital">and</hi> pinastellus, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Herb. 94</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
sispes: <entryFree id="n44479" type="gloss" key="sispe^s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">sispĕs</orth>, <itype>ĭtis</itype>, v. sospes <sense id="n44479.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">init.</hi></sense></entryFree>
sisto: <entryFree id="n44480" type="main" key="sisto"><orth extent="full" lang="la">sisto</orth>, <itype>stĭti</itype> (<bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 220</bibl>, and <bibl default="NO"><author>Diom.</author> p. 369</bibl>, give steti for both sisto and sto, confining stiti to the compounds of both. But steti, as perfect of sisto, is late jurid. Lat., and perh. dub.; <sense id="n44480.0" n="I" level="1"><cit><quote lang="la">for steterant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:110" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 110</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">steterint,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 403</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:32:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 32, 12</bibl>, belong to stare; cf. also <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:2:14:1" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 2, 14, 1</bibl> sqq.; and v. Neue, Formenl. 2, 461 sq.), stătum [root stă, strengthened by reduplication; cf. <foreign lang="greek">i(/sthmi</foreign>], used in two general senses, I. <hi rend="ital">To cause to stand</hi>, <hi rend="ital">place</hi>, = colloco, pono; II. <hi rend="ital">To stand</hi>, <hi rend="ital">be placed</hi>, = sto. </sense><sense id="n44480.1" n="I" level="1"> Sistere, in gen., = collocare (in class. prose only in the partic. uses, v. A. 4. C. and D., infra). </sense><sense id="n44480.2" n="A" level="2"> Causative, with <case>acc.</case> </sense><sense id="n44480.3" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To place</hi> = facere ut stet; constr. with <hi rend="ital">in</hi> and <case>abl.</case>, with <case>abl.</case> alone, and with <hi rend="ital">ad</hi>, <hi rend="ital">super</hi>, etc., and <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">O qui me gelidis in vallibus Haemi Sistat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:489" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 489</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tertia lux classem Cretaeis sistet in oris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:117" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 3, 117</bibl></cit> (classis stat; <cit><quote lang="la">v. sto): inque tuo celerem litore siste gradum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:13:102" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 13, 102</bibl></cit> (cf. infra, III. 2. A.): <cit><quote lang="la">jaculum clamanti (al. clamantis) sistit in ore,</quote> <trans><tr>plants the dart in his face</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:10:323" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 10, 323</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">disponit quas in fronte manus, medio quas robore sistat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:7:393" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 7, 393</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">(equum ligneum) sacratā sistimus arā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:245" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 245</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aeternis potius me pruinis siste,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:4:395" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 4, 395</bibl></cit>: ut stata (est) lux pelago, <hi rend="ital">as soon as light was set</hi> (<hi rend="ital">shone</hi>) <hi rend="ital">on the sea</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 476</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">victima Sistitur ante aras,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:15:132" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 15, 132</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quam (suem) Aeneas ubi ... sistit ad aram,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:85" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 85</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">post haec Sistitur crater,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:8:669" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 8, 669</bibl></cit>: vestigia in altero (monte) sisti (non posse), <hi rend="ital">that no footprints can be placed</hi> (<hi rend="ital">made</hi>) <hi rend="ital">on the other mountain</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:211" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 96, 98, § 211</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cohortes expeditas super caput hostium sistit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:77" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 77</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:12:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 12, 13</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:4:445" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 4, 445</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:4:612" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 4, 612</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n44480.4" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To place</hi>, as the result of guidance or conveyance; hence, <hi rend="ital">to convey</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to send</hi>, <hi rend="ital">lead</hi>, <hi rend="ital">take</hi>, <hi rend="ital">conduct to</hi>, = facere ut veniat; constr. with <hi rend="ital">in</hi> and <case>abl.</case>, with <case>abl.</case> alone, and with <hi rend="ital">advv. of place</hi>: officio meo ripā sistetur in illā Haec, <hi rend="ital">will be carried by me to</hi>, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:9:109" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 9, 109</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">terrā sistēre petitā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:3:635" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 635</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">(vos) facili jam tramite sistam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:676" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 676</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut eum in Syriā aut Aegypto sisterent orabat,</quote> <trans><tr>to convey him to</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 2, 9</bibl></cit>.—So with <hi rend="ital">hic</hi> (= <hi rend="ital">in</hi> with <case>abl.</case>) or <hi rend="ital">huc</hi> (= <hi rend="ital">in</hi> with <case>acc.</case>): <cit><quote lang="la">hic siste patrem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Phoen. 121" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Phoen. 121</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Annam huc siste sororem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:634" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 634</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n44480.5" n="3" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To place an army in order of battle</hi>, <hi rend="ital">draw up</hi>, = instruere: <cit><quote lang="la">aciem in litore sistit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:10:309" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 10, 309</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">sistere tertiam decimam legionem in ipso aggere jubet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 21</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n44480.6" n="4" level="3"> Se sistere = <hi rend="ital">to betake one's self</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to present one's self</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to come</hi> (so twice in Cicero's letters): <cit><quote lang="la">des operam, id quod mihi affirmasti, ut te ante Kal. Jan., ubicumque erimus, sistas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:3:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 3, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">te vegetum nobis in Graeciā sistas,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 10, 16, 6</bibl></cit> (cf. infra, E.): <cit><quote lang="la">hic dea se primum rapido pulcherrima nisu Sistit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:11:853" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 11, 853</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n44480.7" n="5" level="3"> With two <case>acc.</case> (cf.: praesto, reddo) = <hi rend="ital">to cause to be in a certain condition</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to place</hi>, etc.; often with <hi rend="ital">dat. of interest</hi> (ante- and post-class., and <usg type="style">poet.</usg>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">supra, 4.): ego vos salvos sistam,</quote> <trans><tr>I will place you in safety</tr>, <tr>see you to a safe place</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:4:4:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 4, 4, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnia salva sistentur tibi,</quote> <trans><tr>all will be returned to you in good order</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 3, 3</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">suam rem sibi salvam sistam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:5:2:123" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Poen. 5, 2, 123</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">rectius tacitas tibi res sistam, quam quod dictum est mutae mulieri,</quote> <trans><tr>will keep your secrets</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 2, 54</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">neque (dotem) incolumem sistere illi, et detraxe autument,</quote> <trans><tr>that you deliver it entire to her</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:3:3:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Trin. 3, 3, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum te reducem aetas prospera sistet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:64:238" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 64, 238</bibl></cit>: tu modo servitio vacuum me siste (= praesta) superbo, <hi rend="ital">set</hi> <cb n="SIST" /> <hi rend="ital">me free from</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:4:16" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 4, 16</bibl> (3, 17), 42: <cit><quote lang="la">tutum patrio te limine sistam,</quote> <trans><tr>will see you safe home</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:620" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 620</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">praedā onustos triumphantesque mecum domos reduces sistatis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:29:27:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 29, 27, 3</bibl></cit> Weissenb. ad loc.: <cit><quote lang="la">Pelasgis siste levem campum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:8:328" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 8, 328</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">modo se isdem in terris victorem sisterent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">operā tuā sistas hunc nobis sanum atque validum,</quote> <trans><tr>give him back to us</tr>, <tr>safe and sound</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:18:10:7" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 18, 10, 7</bibl></cit>: ita mihi salvam ac sospitem rempublicam sistere in suā sede liceat, Aug. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:28" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 28</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n44480.8" n="b" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">Neutr</hi>, with double <case>nom.</case>, = exsistere, <hi rend="ital">to be</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to become</hi>: judex extremae sistet vitaeque necisque, <hi rend="ital">he will become a judge</hi>, etc., <bibl default="NO"><author>Manil.</author> 4, 548</bibl> (dub.): <cit><quote lang="la">tempora quod sistant propriis parentia signis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> 3, 529</bibl></cit> (dub.; al. sic stant; cf. infra, II.).—</sense><sense id="n44480.9" n="B" level="2"> As <hi rend="ital">neuter verb</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to stand</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rest</hi>, <hi rend="ital">be placed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">lie</hi> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg>); <cit><quote lang="la">constr. like sto: ne quis mihi obstiterit obviam, nam qui obstiterit, ore sistet,</quote> <trans><tr>will lie on his face</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:4:2:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 4, 2, 13</bibl></cit> Brix ad loc.: (nemo sit) tantā gloriā ... quin cadat, quin capite sistat, <hi rend="ital">will be placed</hi> or <hi rend="ital">stand on his head</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:2:3:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Curc. 2, 3, 8</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ibi crebro, credo, capite sistebant cadi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:3:2:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 3, 2, 36</bibl></cit> Lorenz (Brix, hoc illi crebro capite): <cit><quote lang="la">ipsum si quicquam posse in se sistere credis,</quote> <trans><tr>to rest upon itself</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:1057" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 1057</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">neque posse in terrā sistere terram,</quote> <trans><tr>nor can the earth rest upon itself</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:603" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 2, 603</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">at conlectus aquae ... qui lapides inter sistit per strata viarum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:415" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 4, 415</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">incerti quo fata ferant, ubi sistere detur,</quote> <trans><tr>to rest</tr>, <tr>to stay</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 7</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">quaesitisque diu terris, ubi sistere detur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:307" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 1, 307</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n44480.10" n="C" level="2"> As jurid. term. </sense><sense id="n44480.11" n="1" level="3"> In both a causative and neuter sense = <hi rend="ital">to produce in court</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">to appear in court after being bound over by the judge or by promise to the adversary</hi> (vadimonium); constr. either <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi> or with the <case>dat.</case> of the adversary to whom the promise is made (alicui sisti), <hi rend="ital">to appear upon somebody's demand;</hi> also, in judicio sisti. The present active is either used reflexively (se sistere = <hi rend="ital">to appear</hi>), or with a transitive object (sistere aliquem = <hi rend="ital">to produce</hi> in court one in whose behalf the promise has been made). The present passive, sisti, sistendus, sistitur, = <hi rend="ital">to appear</hi> or <hi rend="ital">to be produced.</hi> The perfect act., stiti, stitisse, rarely the perfect passive, status sum, = <hi rend="ital">to have appeared</hi>, <hi rend="ital">I appeared.</hi> So in all periods of the language: <cit><quote lang="la">cum autem in jus vocatus fuerit adversarius, ni eo die finitum fuerit negotium, vadimonium ei faciendum est, id est ut promittat se certo die sisti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1251,001:4:184" default="NO"><author>Gai.</author> 4, 184</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fit ut Alfenus promittat, Naevio sisti Quinctium,</quote> <trans><tr>that Quinctius would be forthcoming upon Naevius's complaint</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Quint. 21, 67</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 8, 30</bibl> (v. infra, B.): <cit><quote lang="la">testificatur, P. Quinctium non stitisse, et se stitisse,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 6, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quin puellam sistendam promittat (= fore ut puella sistatur in judicio),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:45:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 45, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">interrogavit quisquam, in quem diem locumque vadimonium promitti juberet, et Scipio manum ad ipsam oppidi, quod obsidebatur, arcem protendens: Perendie sese sistant illo in loco,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:7:1:10" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 7, 1, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si quis quendam in judicio sisti promiserit, in eādem causā eum debet sistere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:2:11:11" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 2, 11, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si servum in eādem causā sistere promiserit, et liber factus sistatur, ... non recte sistitur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:2:9:5" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 2, 9, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sed si statu liberum sisti promissum sit, in eādem causā sisti videtur, quamvis liber sistatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:2:9:6" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 2, 9, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum quis in judicio sisti promiserit, neque adjecerit poenam si status non esset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:2:6:4" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 2, 6, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si quis in judicio secundum suam promissionem non stitit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:2:11:2:section=1" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 2, 11, 2, § 1</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:2:5:1" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 2, 5, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:2:8:2" default="NO">2, 8, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:2:11:2:section=3" default="NO">2, 11, 2, § 3</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n44480.12" n="2" level="3"> Vadimonium sistere, <hi rend="ital">to present one's self in court</hi>, <hi rend="ital">thus keeping the solemn engagement</hi> (vadimonium) <hi rend="ital">made to that effect;</hi> lit., <hi rend="ital">to make the vadimonium stand</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">effective</hi>, opp. deserere vadimonium = <hi rend="ital">not to appear</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to forfeit the vadimonium.</hi> The phrase does not occur in the jurists of the Pandects, the institution of the vadimonium being abolished by Marcus Aurelius. It is found in the following three places only: quid si vadimonium capite obvoluto stitisses? Cat. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:2:14:1" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 2, 14, 1</bibl>: ut Quinctium sisti Alfenus promitteret. Venit Romam Quinctius; <cit><quote lang="la">vadimonium sistit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Quint. 8, 30</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut nullum illa stiterit vadimonium sine Attico,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,025:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Att. 9</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1251,001:4:185" default="NO"><author>Gai.</author> 4, 185</bibl>; cf. diem sistere under <itype>status</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos> infra.—</sense><sense id="n44480.13" n="D" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, out of judicial usage, in gen., = <hi rend="ital">to appear</hi> or <hi rend="ital">present one's self</hi>, quasi ex vadimonio; <cb n="SIST" /> constr. <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi> or with <case>dat.</case> of the person entitled to demand the appearance: <cit><quote lang="la">ubi tu es qui me vadatus's Veneriis vadimoniis? Sisto ego tibi me, et mihi contra itidem ted ut sistas suadeo (of a lover's appointment),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:1:3:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Curc. 1, 3, 5</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">tibi amatorem illum alacrem vadimonio sistam,</quote> <trans><tr>produce</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 9, p. 227, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nam promisimus carnufici aut talentum magnum, aut hunc hodie sistere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:3:4:73" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 3, 4, 73</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vas factus est alter ejus sistendi, ut si ille non revertisset, moriendum esset sibi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:10:45" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 3, 10, 45</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n44480.14" n="E" level="2"> Fana sistere, acc. to Festus anciently used, either = <hi rend="ital">to place</hi> (<hi rend="ital">secure and fix places for</hi>) temples in founding a city, or <hi rend="ital">to place</hi> the couches in the lectisternia: <cit><quote lang="la">sistere fana, cum in urbe condendā dicitur, significat loca in oppido futurorum fanorum constituere: quamquam Antistius Labeo, in commentario XV. juris pontificii ait fana sistere esse lectisternia certis locis et diebus habere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=267" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 267</bibl></cit> Lind. To this usage Plaut. perh. alludes: <cit><quote lang="la">apud illas aedis sistendae mihi sunt sycophantiae,</quote> <trans><tr>the place about that house I must make the scene of my tricks</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:4:2:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 4, 2, 25</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n44480.15" n="F" level="1"> Sistere monumenta, etc., or sistere alone, <hi rend="ital">to erect</hi> statues, etc. (= statuere; post-class. and rare; <cit><quote lang="la">mostly in Tac.): ut apud Palatium effigies eorum sisteret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:15:72" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 15, 72</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum Augustus sibi templum sisti non prohibuisset,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4</bibl></cit> 37: <cit><quote lang="la">at Romae tropaea de Parthis arcusque sistebantur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 15, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">monuere ut ... templum iisdem vestigiis sisteretur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:4:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 4, 53</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sistere monumenta,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Ep. 24, 55</bibl></cit>: Ast ego te ... Carthaginis arce Marmoreis sistam templis (cf. <foreign lang="greek">i(sta/nai tina/</foreign>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:8:231" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 8, 231</bibl>; v. statuo.</sense><sense id="n44480.16" n="II" level="1"> Sistere = <hi rend="ital">to cause</hi> what is tottering or loose <hi rend="ital">to stand firm</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to support</hi> or <hi rend="ital">fasten;</hi> and <hi rend="ital">neutr.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to stand firm.</hi> </sense><sense id="n44480.17" n="A" level="2"> Causative (rare; <cit><quote lang="la">perh. not in class. prose) = stabilire: sucus ... mobilis (dentes) sistit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:20:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 20, 3, 8, § 15</bibl></cit>; and trop.: hic (Marcellus) rem Romanam magno turbante tumultu Sistet (cf.: respublica stat; <cit><quote lang="la">v. sto),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:858" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 858</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">non ita civitatem aegram esse, ut consuetis remediis sisti posset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:20:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 20, 8</bibl></cit> (where sisti may be <hi rend="ital">impers.;</hi> <xr><lbl>v.</lbl> <ref type="sym" targOrder="U">infra</ref></xr>, III. C.).—</sense><sense id="n44480.18" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Neutr.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to stand firm</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to last</hi>, = stare: <cit><quote lang="la">nec mortale genus, nec divum corpora sancta Exiguom possent horai sistere tempus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:1016" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 1016</bibl></cit>: qui rem publicam sistere negat posse, nisi ad equestrem ordinem judicia referantur, Cotta ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:96:section=223" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 96, § 223</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n44480.19" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Neutr.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to stand firm</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to resist</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec quicquam Teucros Sustentare valet telis, aut sistere contra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:11:873" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 11, 873</bibl></cit>; so with <case>dat.</case> = resistere: <cit><quote lang="la">donec Galba, inruenti turbae neque aetate neque corpore sistens, sella levaretur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 1, 35</bibl></cit>; cf. sisti = resistere, III. B. 1. f. infra.</sense><sense id="n44480.20" n="III" level="1"> Sistere = <hi rend="ital">to stand still</hi>, and <hi rend="ital">to cause to stand still.</hi> </sense><sense id="n44480.21" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Neutr.</hi> = stare (rare; in Varr., Tac., and the poets). </sense><sense id="n44480.22" n="a" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">To stand still</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">solstitium dictum est quod sol eo die sistere videatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 5, p. 53" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 5, p. 53</bibl></cit> (Bip.): <cit><quote lang="la">sistunt amnes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:479" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 1, 479</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">incurrit, errat, sistit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Herc. Oet. 248" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Herc. Oet. 248</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n44480.23" n="b" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">To remain</hi>, <hi rend="ital">stop</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Siste! Quo praeceps ruis?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Thyest. 77" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Thyest. 77</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Oedip. 1050" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Oedip. 1050</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">vis tu quidem istum intra locum sistere?</quote> <trans><tr>will you remain in that position?</tr></trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 40</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n44480.24" n="c" level="4"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to stop</hi>, <hi rend="ital">not to go any farther</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">depunge, ubi sistam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0969,001:6:79" default="NO"><author>Pers.</author> 6, 79</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec in Hectore tracto sistere,</quote> <trans><tr>to stop at the dragging of Hector</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Achill. 1, 7</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n44480.25" n="d" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">To cease</hi> (dub.): <cit><quote lang="la">hactenus sistat nefas' pius est,</quote> <trans><tr>if his crime ceases here</tr>, <tr>he will be pious</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Thyest. 744" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Thyest. 744</bibl></cit> (perh. <hi rend="ital">act.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to stop</hi>, <hi rend="ital">end</hi>).—</sense><sense id="n44480.26" n="B" level="2"> Causative (not ante-Aug.; freq. in Tac., Plin., and the poets). </sense><sense id="n44480.27" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To arrest</hi>, <hi rend="ital">stop</hi>, <hi rend="ital">check</hi> an advancing motion. </sense><sense id="n44480.28" n="a" level="4"> With <hi rend="ital">gradum</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">plano sistit uterque gradum,</quote> <trans><tr>arrest their steps</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:5" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 5</bibl></cit> (4), 10, 36; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:465" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 465</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">siste properantem gradum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Herc. Fur. 772" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Herc. Fur. 772</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">repente sistunt gradum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:4:6:14" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 4, 6, 14</bibl></cit>. —With <hi rend="ital">pedem</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> R. Am. 80</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n44480.29" n="b" level="4"> With <hi rend="ital">fugam</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to stop</hi>, <hi rend="ital">stay</hi>, <hi rend="ital">check</hi>, <hi rend="ital">stem</hi>, <hi rend="ital">arrest the flight</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">fugam foedam siste,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:12:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 12, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si periculo suo fugam sistere posset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:30:12:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 30, 12, 1</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:8:14:37" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 8, 14, 37</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:4:16:2" default="NO">4, 16, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:8:3:2" default="NO">8, 3, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:12:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 12, 39</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n44480.30" n="c" level="4"> Of vehicles, horses, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">esseda siste,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:2:1:76" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 2, 1, 76</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">equos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:12:355" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 12, 355</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quadrijugos,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Achill. 2, 429</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:5:364" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Th. 5, 364</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n44480.31" n="d" level="4"> With <hi rend="ital">iter</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to arrest the advance of an army</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to halt</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">exercitus iter sistit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 50</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n44480.32" n="e" level="4"> With <hi rend="ital">bellum</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to halt</hi> (cf. infra, D.): <cit><quote lang="la">Aquilejae sisti bellum expectarique Mucianum jubebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3</bibl></cit>, <pb n="1712" /> <cb n="SIST" /> 8.—</sense><sense id="n44480.33" n="f" level="4"> Of living objects, in gen. </sense><sense id="n44480.34" n="(a)" level="5"> <hi rend="ital">To arrest their course</hi>, <hi rend="ital">make them halt</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aegre coercitam legionem Bedriaci sistit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 2, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">festinantia sistens Fata,</quote> <trans><tr>staying the hurrying Fates</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:3:4:24" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 3, 4, 24</bibl></cit>.—So, se sistere with <hi rend="ital">ab</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to desist from</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">non prius se ab effuso cursu sistunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:29:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 6, 29, 3</bibl></cit>; hence, <hi rend="ital">to arrest by wounding</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">to wound</hi> or <hi rend="ital">kill</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquem cuspide,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:1:382" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 1, 382</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:1:163" default="NO">1, 163</bibl>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">cervum vulnere sistere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:2:78" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 2, 78</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n44480.35" n="(b)" level="5"> <hi rend="ital">To stop a hostile attack of persons</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to resist them</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ward them off</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut non sisterent modo Sabinas legiones, sed in fugam averterent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:37:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 37, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ibi integrae vires sistunt invehentem se jam Samnitem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:10:14:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 10, 14, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec sisti vis hostium poterat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:5:3:11" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 5, 3, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec sisti poterant scandentes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:71" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 71</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">5, 21</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n44480.36" n="g" level="4"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to stop the advance of prices</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">pretia augeri in dies, nec mediocribus remediis sisti posse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:3:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 3, 52</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n44480.37" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To arrest the motion</hi> of fluids. </sense><sense id="n44480.38" n="a" level="4"> Of water: <cit><quote lang="la">sistere aquam fluviis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:489" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 489</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amnis, siste parumper aquas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:3:6:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> Am. 3, 6, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae concita flumina sistunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:7:154" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> M. 7, 154</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sistito infestum mare,</quote> <trans><tr>calm</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Agam. 523" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Agam. 523</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:7:200" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 7, 200</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:6:87" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 6, 87</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:28:118" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 28, 8, 29, § 118</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n44480.39" n="b" level="4"> Of blood and secretions: <cit><quote lang="la">(ea) quibus sistitur sanguis parari jubet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:15:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 15, 54</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sanguinem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:20:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 20, 7, 25, § 59</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:28:239" default="NO" valid="yes">28, 18, 73, § 239</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:27:18" default="NO" valid="yes">27, 4, 5, § 18</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">haemorrhoidum abundantiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:27:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 27, 4, 5, § 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fluctiones,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:20:71:34:10:23:section=105" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 20, 8, 27, § 71, 34, 10, 23, § 105</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:35:195" default="NO" valid="yes">35, 17, 57, § 195</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nomas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:30:116" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 30, 13, 39, § 116</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:24:151" default="NO" valid="yes">24, 16, 94, § 151</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">mensis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:23:112" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 23, 6, 60, § 112</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vomitiones,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:20:213" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 20, 20, 81, § 213</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alvum bubus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:18:143" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 18, 16, 42, § 143</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alvum,</quote> <trans><tr>stop the bowels</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:23:113" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 23, 6, 60, § 113</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:22:126" default="NO" valid="yes">22, 25, 59, § 126</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:20:37" default="NO" valid="yes">20, 5, 18, § 37</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ventrem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:20:256" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 20, 23, 96, § 256</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:13:116" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 13, 116</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n44480.40" n="3" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To arrest the motion of life</hi>, <hi rend="ital">make rigid</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ille oculos sistit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:2:539" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 2, 539</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n44480.41" n="4" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To end</hi>, <hi rend="ital">put an end to</hi> (= finem facere alicui rei); <hi rend="ital">pass.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to cease</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">querelas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:7:711" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 7, 711</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fletus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:14:835" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 14, 835</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lacrimas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:1:367" default="NO"><author>id.</author> F. 1, 367</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">480</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">6, 154</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">minas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:1:2:60" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tr. 1, 2, 60</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">opus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 16</bibl></cit> (17), 266; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:3:153" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> M. 3, 153</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">labores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:5:490" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 490</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">furorem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:5:663" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 5, 663</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">furialem impetum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Med. 157" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Med. 157</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Agam. 203" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Agam. 203</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">pace tamen sisti bellum placet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:803" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 803</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">antequam summa dies spectacula sistat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:4:387" default="NO"><author>id.</author> F. 4, 387</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sitim sistere,</quote> <trans><tr>to allay</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:3:1:18" default="NO"><author>id.</author> P. 3, 1, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec primo in limine sistit conatus scelerum,</quote> <trans><tr>suppresses</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:5:2:86" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 5, 2, 86</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ruinas,</quote> <trans><tr>to stop destruction</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,002:50:4" default="NO"><author>Plin.</author> Pan. 50, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ventum,</quote> <trans><tr>to ward off</tr>, <tr>turn the wind</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:2:17:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ep. 2, 17, 17</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">(motus terrae) non ante quadraginta dies sistuntur, = desinunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:198" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 82, 84, § 198</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n44480.42" n="5" level="3"> Sistere with <hi rend="ital">intra</hi> = <hi rend="ital">to confine</hi>, <hi rend="ital">keep within</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">transgresso jam Alpes Caecina, quem sisti intra Gallias posse speraverant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 2, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dum populatio lucem intra sisteretur,</quote> <trans><tr>provided the raids were confined to day-time</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 4, 48</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n44480.43" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Impers.</hi> and trop., <hi rend="ital">to arrest</hi> or <hi rend="ital">avoid an impending misfortune</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">to stand</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">to endure;</hi> generally in the form sisti non potest (more rarely: sisti potest) = <hi rend="ital">it cannot be endured</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a disaster cannot be avoided</hi> or <hi rend="ital">met</hi> (once in Plaut.; freq. in Liv.; sometimes in Tac.; cf., in gen., Brix ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:720" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 720</bibl>; Drak. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:16:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 16, 4</bibl>; Weissenb. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:29:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 29, 8</bibl>; Gronov. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:12:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 12, 6</bibl>; Beneke ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:11:1:6" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 11, 1, 6</bibl>). </sense><sense id="n44480.44" n="1" level="3"> Without a subject, res or a noun of general import being understood: <cit><quote lang="la">quid ego nunc agam, nisi ut clipeum ad dorsum accommodem, etc.? Non sisti potest,</quote> <trans><tr>it is intolerable</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:3:2:94" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 3, 2, 94</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">totam plebem aere alieno demersam esse, nec sisti posse nisi omnibus consulatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:29:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 29, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si domestica seditio adiciatur, sisti non posse,</quote> <trans><tr>the situation will be desperate</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:45:19:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 45, 19, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si quem similem priore anno dedissent, non potuisse sisti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:9:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 3, 9, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vixque concordiā sisti videbatur,</quote> <trans><tr>that the crisis could scarcely be met</tr>, <tr>even by harmonious action</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:16:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 3, 16, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">qualicunque urbis statu, manente disciplinā militari sisti potuisse,</quote> <trans><tr>these evils were endurable</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:44:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 2, 44, 10</bibl></cit>: exercitum gravi morbo affectari, nec sisti potuisse ni, etc., <hi rend="ital">it would have ended in disaster</hi>, <hi rend="ital">if not</hi>, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:29:10:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 29, 10, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui omnes populi si pariter deficiant, sisti nullo modo posse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:11:1:6" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 11, 1, 6</bibl></cit> Gronov. ad loc.; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:20:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 20, 8</bibl> supra, II. A. 1.— Rarely with a <hi rend="ital">subject-clause</hi> understood: nec jam sisti poterat, <hi rend="ital">and it was no longer tolerable</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">that Nero should disgrace himself</hi>, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:14:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 14, 14</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n44480.45" n="2" level="3"> Rarely with <hi rend="ital">quin</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to prevent</hi> etc. (pregn., implying also <cb n="SISY" /> the stopping of something; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">supra, III. B. 1.): neque sisti potuit quin et palatium et domus et cuncta circum haurirentur (igni),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:15:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 15, 39</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">stătus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, as attribute of nouns, occurs in several conventional phrases, as relics of archaic usage. </sense><sense id="n44480.46" n="A" level="2"> Status (condictusve) dies cum hoste, in the XII. Tables, = <hi rend="ital">a day of trial</hi> fixed by the judge or agreed upon with the adversary; <cit><quote lang="la">esp., a peregrinus (= hostis),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:12:37" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 12, 37</bibl></cit>. It presupposes a phrase, diem sistere, prob.=vadimonium sistere (v. supra, I. C. 2.). Such an appointment was an excuse from the most important public duties, even for soldiers from joining the army, Cinc. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:16:4:4" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 16, 4, 4</bibl>.— <cit><quote lang="la">Hence, transf.: si status condictus cum hoste intercedit dies, tamen est eundum quo imperant,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>under all circumstances we must go</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:1:1:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Curc. 1, 1, 5</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n44480.47" n="B" level="2"> In certain phrases, <hi rend="ital">appointed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fixed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">regular</hi> (cf. statutus, with which it is often confounded in MSS.): <cit><quote lang="la">status dies: tres in anno statos dies habere quibus, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:39:13:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 39, 13, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">stato loco statisque diebus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:42:32:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 42, 32, 2</bibl></cit>;
